grounding: The origin of modern eukaryotes is one of the key transitions in life's history, and also one of the least understood. Although the fossil record provides the most direct view of this process, interpreting the fossils of early eukaryotes and eukaryote-grade organisms is not straightforward. We present two end-member models for the evolution of modern (i.e., crown) eukaryotes—one in which modern eukaryotes evolved early, and another in which they evolved late—and interpret key fossils within these frameworks, including where they might fit in eukaryote phylogeny and what they may tell us about the evolution of eukaryotic cell biology and ecology. Each model has different implications for understanding the rise of complex life on Earth, including different roles of Earth surface oxygenation, and makes different predictions that future paleontological studies can test.
generated_text: The early fossil record of eukaryotes presents a complex puzzle, with interpretations often hindered by the scarcity and ambiguous nature of Precambrian fossils. This study reviews current frameworks for interpreting these ancient remains, focusing on the Proterozoic eon, a critical period for eukaryogenesis. We explore the impact of the Great Oxidation Event on eukaryotic evolution, considering how increased atmospheric oxygen levels may have facilitated the emergence and diversification of eukaryotes. By integrating paleontological, geochemical, and molecular data, we propose a multidisciplinary approach to decipher the early history of eukaryotes. Our analysis highlights the importance of distinguishing between biogenic and non-biogenic structures in the fossil record and underscores the need for refined dating techniques to better understand the timing and environmental context of eukaryotic origins. This research contributes to a more nuanced understanding of early eukaryotic evolution and its environmental drivers.
